document:
Documents usually have some form of “logical structure”: division into chapters, sections, sub-sections etc. to organize their content. LaTeX supports the creation of a document structure and also enables customization of sectioning and numbering. The commands available to organize a document depend on the document class being used, although the simplest form of organization, sectioning, is available in all formats.

Let’s begin with a basic example to demonstrate the command, which marks the beginning of a new section called . Section numbering is automatic and can be customized, or disabled.

Open this example in Overleaf.



 This example produces the following output:

LaTeX can organize, number, and index chapters and sections of document. There are up to 7 levels of depth for defining sections depending on the document class:

Usually, is the top-level document command in most documents. However, in reports or books, and similar long documents, this would be or .

To get an unnumbered chapter, section, subsection, etc. add an asterisk ( ) at the end of the command, before the opening curly brace. These will not go into the table of contents. Here is our first example (above) but this time using instead of :

There are two general commands:

where and are optional parameters, and:
• is the sectioning command to be redefined: , , , , , or .
• is sectioning paragraph shape; possible values are: , , , , , , , and .
• is the format to be applied to the title, label, and text; for example
• is the horizontal separation between label and title body and it must be a length and not be empty.
• is code following the title body.
• is the vertical space before the title.
• is the separation between title and non-sectioning text.

The starred version of this command ( ) kills the indentation of the paragraph following the title.

A package providing an interface to sectioning commands for selection from various title styles. E.g., marginal titles and to change the font of all headings with a single command, also providing simple one-step page styles. Also includes a package to change the page styles when there are floats in a page. You may assign headers/footers to individual floats, too.

Download the contents of this package in one zip archive (695.1k).
